amine achergui wrote:
> Hi everyone,
> I'm now using as for mocking jmock but i want to know if it's the best
> choice.
> the fact, that the expectation for a method call are based on the method
> name wich is passed as string .
> It let's the test code less coupled to the mocked class on compile time
> (because of the declarative approach).
> code snippet:
> mock.expects(once()).method("mymethod").with(eq(param));
> In easyMock the excpectations are the calls on methods on the mock done in
> the record part(programmatic approach).
> code snippet:
> mock.mymethod(param);
> thus, if the signature of the method changes in the mocked collaborator
> easymock will signal this at compile time of the tests.
> it might not to be a big difference but easymock approach seems to be very
> tied to the interface of the mocked class because of the code of the tests
> is a copy of the mocked class test.(It doesn't meen that in jmock the
> sequence of the calls are not repeated but it's not as clear as in easy and
> it's possibly to stubs (in jmock context) for  an expectation of a method
> call that can be called 0 or many times ).
> what do you think?

When I wrote _JUnit Recipes_, my examples used EasyMock. I liked it 
because it was simple for the simplest case of setting expectations.

When I started using jMock, I much preferred it, because:

1. It has direct support for fakes/stubs.
2. It makes ignoring method parameters easy.
3. Its support for complex parameter, method or invocation matching is 
great.

If there is ever a 2nd edition of _JUnit Recipes_, I will replace all 
the EasyMock example code with jMock.

The people who don't like jMock often say it's because declaring the 
method names as strings makes refactoring more error-prone. That might 
be the case, but I have never felt pain as a result of it.

I hope that helps.
